{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3539250,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-25T14:08:24.293Z","cooked":"

We’re testing pose estimates so we can do odometry updates.

We have 2xLL2+ and 2xLL4. I reloaded all of them with 2025.1 firmware and loaded 2025 Andymark Apriltag map. I did NOT do custom Apriltag calibration after that for any of them (may be I should?).

We’re only interested in coordinates from the BLUE bottom size of the field being the origin (meaning we track everything in absolute coordinates)

I guess I am not doing something right, but I found the following:

  1. On LL2+ the Megatag pose puts me on a BLUE side of the field (which is correct for the tag I am looking at), but Megatag2 shows me on the RED side (???)
  2. The coordinates the cameras tell me I am at do not seem to match the coordinates I suppose to be at with somewhat large discrepancy (e.g 0.3 meters in some cases)

That did not happen last year. Last year measurements on LL2+ were pretty precise.

Note that the way I measure is a relative distance between AprilTag and the bot (and recalculating those with trigonometry). And I get coordinates of the AprilTag from the WPI class map (may be those are wrong??)

Are you providing your gyro measurement? For megatag 2 you have to provide the rotation measurement from your bots gyro. If that is incorrect or not provided you will get bad results.

I do not! For manual kind of measurement - where do I indicate them?

use the set robot orientation in the limelight helpers class. Your gyro has to be correctly seeded when your robot comes up.

LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation

Is there any way to do so in the LL interface? Meaning - I wanted to see if the camera gives me the right numbers on the LL GUI, if possible. Any place to put the IMU there so it will tell me where I am?

atsekhan:

Is there any way to do so in the LL interface?

Don’t have the LL in front of me to know, but I don’t think so If you do have your robot reporting orientation though you will see the position calculated off of it in the LL interface.

I will try tonight. So far all measurements and numbers were off the LLL GUI and not from the code.

Also it seems LL4 does have internal IMU that I can set and see the poses. But I will also see if I can set a pose in the code and whether that makes a difference.
Megatag1 produced results that were way too “wrong”

In my experience Megatag 1 did have stability and accuracy issues. I tried to never use Megatag1 with less that 2 tags in view and i gave that lower confidence than 3+ tags

Update - ran the IMU updated to all LLs in periodic.

Much better! Megatag2 is finally working and gives numbers much more precise even with the single AprilTag.

Thanks for the help!

Can you show me with an example how you fixed it? I’m having the same problem

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T12:41:24.867Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":34.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":493123,"topic_slug":"limelights-gives-incorrect-pose-estimate","display_username":"Krypton #9487","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50762,"username":"atsekhan","name":"Alex Tsekhansky","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60531,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelights-gives-incorrect-pose-estimate/493123/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3540949,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T12:50:16.907Z","cooked":"

Absolutely. The idea was to do this:

github.com

FRC999/2025Competition/blob/3ba6163701a258876c8e1f3c2584f84961751a56/C2025_release/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/LLVisionSubsystem.java#L76


      
    
          
  1.       int tagId = 1;
    2. 
          
  2.       Pose3d tagPose = fieldLayout.getTagPose(tagId).orElse(null);
    3. 
          
  3. 
          
  4.       if (tagPose != null) {
    5. 
          
  5.           System.out.println("AprilTag " + tagId + " Pose: " + tagPose);
    6. 
          
  6.       } else {
    7. 
          
  7.           System.out.println("AprilTag " + tagId + " not found in the field layout.");
    8. 
          
  8.       }
    9. 
          
  9.     }
    10. 
          
  10. 
          
  11.      for (LLCamera llcamera : LLCamera.values()) {
    12. 
          
  12.       String cn = llcamera.getCameraName();
    13. 
          
  13. 
          
  14.       double yaw = RobotContainer.driveSubsystem.getYaw();
    15. 
          
  15.       double yawrate = RobotContainer.driveSubsystem.getTurnRate();
    16. 
          
  16.       LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation(cn, yaw, yawrate, 0, 0, 0, 0);
    17. 
          
  17.      }
    18. 
          
  18.       
    19. 
          
  19.   }
    20. 
          
  20. }
    21. 
          
  21.

Note that we also set LL configuration that includes relative position of LL to the center of the bot. That way LL automatically recalculates what it sees into the bot position vs camera position. We set those on the cameras directly vs in the code (which in retrospect probably should be in a code in case we re-flash LL).

What happens is that I don’t have much experience with limelight and vision odometry, I did it based on the example of limelight itself, I would need a larger example, can I send my code for you to see?

So, you use this

"
LimelightHelpers.PoseEstimate mt1 = LimelightHelpers.getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue(“limelight”);
"

to get the pose.

You’re not really updating the odometry, right? If you do, where do you do it exactly? Updating odometry really means changing your Pose2d and possibly dynamic parameters (e.g. velocity) of your bot.

For instance, if you use CTR template for the drive, they have a method -

that is a part of the SwerveDriveTrain class

So if your odometry is internal to CTR (meaning - you do not really need to update it manually, except possibly vision), then you can use a method like that.

You can also, of course, brute-force set odometry to a pose (again - this particular code is specific to CTR):

    5. 
          
  5.  * start of the trajectory.
    6. 
          
  6.  * Be aware that on-going odometry updates use IMU. So, your odometry yaw may change incorrectly
    7. 
          
  7.  * later if the current yaw is not reset properly on the IMU first.
    8. 
          
  8.  * 
    9. 
          
  9.  * Note that the pose is from Blue Alliance perspective
    10. 
          
  10.  */
    11.

    12. 
          
  12.   this.resetPose(pose);
    13. 
          
  13. }

You have marked this thread solved as the original question was answered but you seem to still question how to do something. If you still have a problem, then consider how you are trying to use these components and describe your problem again:

There is wheel odometry that estimates the robot pose based on how far the wheels have moved.

There is LL pose estimation from the AprilTags.

There is a pose estimator that can use any weighted combination of wheel odometry, gyro reading, and LL pose to compute a pose.

You can reset the wheel odometry based on any other pose but normally the pose estimator when the AprilTags can be highly trusted is used to update the wheel odometry.

This may be a simplistic view of the process but should be good enough for you to tell us where you want help.
